content.description: This is an alternative start to "Guillotine" taking a more direct path to the top crux. Scramble 20' up the loose gully before stepping onto the route with an undercling and right into some steep juggy climbing. Clip a few bolts, using a series of underclings and side pulls to join Guillotine right before the crux. Tricky moves at the very end make for an exciting redpoint crux.
content.protection: 9 bolts to an anchor with fixed steel draws
content.location: Farthest route on the right side of the wall. Begins on red streaked rock.

content.description: Requires a 70M rope to top rope/lower off (or two ropes)
content.protection: 16 bolts to a two bolt anchor w rap rings
content.location: To gain the big ledge, work up the central part of the wall clipping a couple bolts (back cleaning the first bolt will help with rope drag). From the ledge, Shiny Yellow Crane begins in the shallow right facing corner on the left side of the wall.

content.description: The first half of Guillotine stops at the top of the corner system and stays (mostly) dry even in heavy rain.
content.protection: 6 bolts to two bolt anchor w rap rings
content.location: On the right side of the wall, beginning in the little chimney with the "guillotine" chock stone.

content.description: Oso or "Indian Plum" is a native NW plant. In Spanish Oso means bear. The route has a distinct crux halfway, which may be easier for taller people.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a two bolt anchor w rap rings
content.location: Shares start with Kinnikinnick to gain the major ledge system. This route goes up right from the anchor station on the right side of the ledge.

content.description: Kinnikinnick or "bear berry" is a native NW plant. It was used by Native Americans as a smoking herb, with medicinal and spiritual qualities.
content.protection: 8 bolts to two bolt anchor w rap rings
content.location: Shares the first 2 bolts with Oso to gain the major ledge system. This route goes left from the anchor station on the right side of the ledge.

content.description: Named for the ominous chockstone you walk under to start the route. The halfway anchor is for "Rainy Day Woman" 5.9+
content.location: Furthest right on Diablo Wall. Begins in little chimney with microwave-sized chockstone and follows shallow left facing corner

content.description: Shares initial bolts with Shiny Yellow Crane to gain the major ledge 20 feet up the wall.
content.protection: 8 bolts to two bolt anchor w fixed biners. Extension is *open* and looks HARD

content.description: This line was originally left incomplete by a traveling Russian climber. The boulder problem from the upper ledge has caught the attention on many passing climbers over the last 20 years. The project has recently been retro bolted and climbed, clocking in at 5.13a. "Al Tesoro" is spanish for "to the treasure"
content.location: Left side of the wall. Begins on the left most bolted line to the ledge (you can move the belay). From the ledge ,up the steep crimpy boulder problem and on through spicy and steep climbing.

pathTokens: Hwy 20 and North Cascades National Park
